prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Juste output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text: One night two young men from Egulac went down to the river to hunt seals and while they were there it became foggy and calm. Then they heard war-cries, and they thought: 'Maybe this is a war-party'. They escaped to the shore, and hid behind a log. Now canoes came up, and they heard the noise of paddles, and saw one canoe coming up to them. There were five men in the canoe, and they said: 'What do you think? We wish to take you along. We are going up the river to make war on the people.' One of the young men said,'I have no arrows.' 'Arrows are in the canoe,' they said. 'I will not go along. I might be killed. My relatives do not know where I have gone. But you,' he said, turning to the other, 'may go with them.' So one of the young men went, but the other returned home. And the warriors went on up the river to a town on the other side of Kalama. The people came down to the water and they began to fight, and many were killed. But presently the young man heard one of the warriors say, 'Quick, let us go home: that Indian has been hit.' Now he thought: 'Oh, they are ghosts.' He did not feel sick, but they said he had been shot. So the canoes went back to Egulac and the young man went ashore to his house and made a fire. And he told everybody and said: 'Behold I accompanied the ghosts, and we went to fight. Many of our fellows were killed, and many of those who attacked us were killed. They said I was hit, and I did not feel sick.' He told it all, and then he became quiet. When the sun rose he fell down. Something black came out of his mouth. His face became contorted. The people jumped up and cried.He was dead.

stories:
Two young adventurers from the Egulac tribe set off on a moonlit night to the riverbank, intending to hunt seals. The serene atmosphere was shattered by the arrival of a mist, accompanied by stillness. Suddenly, they perceived war cries in the distance. 'Could this be an enemy raid?' they mused. Hastily, they retreated to the safety of the shore, concealing themselves behind a giant log. These ominous signs revealed the approach of an adversarial war canoe. Five armed figures emerged, eagerly beckoning the young men to join their expedition.

One of the adventurers replied, 'My quiver is empty.' Faced with the possibility of losing his life, he hesitated. He was uncertain about the fate of his relatives, who would be unaware of his whereabouts. However, the other man stood firm. "You may journey with them," he suggested to his companion. With a heavy heart, the reluctant young man agreed and subsequently joined their fateful voyage up the river.

As their canoe glided smoothly through the water, they arrived at a distant village, where a vicious battle erupted upon their arrival. The cacophony of weapons clashing filled the air, resulting in numerous fatalities. Amongst the pandemonium, the young man believed he had been struck by an enemy arrow but appeared asymptomatic, grateful for the apparent invisibility to his assailants. He considered the warriors to be supernatural entities.

In time, the canoes bearing the war parties retraced their route back to Egulac. Upon disembarking, the young man felt relieved to be amongst his loved ones and regaled the tale of this otherworldly encounter. As the sun crept above the horizon, however, the decorum of narrative morphed into a ghastly reality. Initially unaware of his true condition, he soon succumbed to his injuries, dying amongst the ashes of his hearth. The grief-stricken tribesmen mourned him, their once vibrant friend now but a tragic emblem of forgotten triumphs and dreams.

Two friends from the village of Wiyot ventured by the river one evening, intending to hunt seals. The tranquility was disrupted as the night fog gave way to eerie war cries, causing them to suspect an impending attack. They hid swiftly behind a large tree, watching as canoes approached. Four brave warriors emerged, summoning the friends to join them.

"I cannot go," one friend protested. "My arrows remain at home, and my family does not know where I might be."

The other friend was hesitant but eventually agreed to accompany the warriors. As they sailed up the river towards a distant village, the village came into view, and the residents gathered along the water's edge to greet their adversaries. Fierce fighting ensued, and many lives were lost on either side. However, amidst the chaos, one of the warriors was struck down.

The remaining friend, not feeling any pain, initially believed the fallen man was a ghost. But when he saw the arrow protruding from his friend's body, he realized it was real. Desperate, the friend pleaded for them to return home. The warriors obliged and sped back to their village, leaving the mortally wounded friend on the shore.

The friend gathering his allies, he declared "I have journeyed with the spirits, and we waged war. Many among our tribe and the enemy perished in the fray. Alas, even I was struck, yet I feel no pain." He detailed every event with great pride and conviction.

As the sun rose, his condition took a turn, and a dark substance began to emerge from his mouth. His facial features distorted, and his loved ones could only watch in horror as the lifeless body of their friend fell to the ground.

Two friends from the village of NAnnotation vollied ventured to the riverbank one evening to hunt for seals. As they waited, the tranquil night was quickly overtaken by a gentle fog. Suddenly, they heard fiery war cries in the distance, their hearts racing in fear as they pondered, 'Perhaps this is an invading party.' In panic, they fled to the protection of the shore, concealing themselves behind the shelter of a large log.

With the sounds of approaching canoes looming near, they grew anxious as five men emerged from the haze. The warriors extended an invitation, "Join us on our journey, as we prepare to wage war against those across the Kalama River." One of the friends hesitated, "I am ill-equipped, I have no arrows."

The war party acknowledged that supplies were plentiful in their canoes, "Arrowheads lie within," they urged. However, our hesitant friend was firmly rooted to his beliefs, "My kinsmen may never know of my whereabouts," leading him to decline the offer.

Turning to his companion, he implored, "But you, my friend, go forth with them in my stead." And so, one young man stepped forward, embarking on the perilous adventure, while the other remained, bound to the safety of his homeland.

As the warriors journeyed up the river, they reached a distant town, inciting conflict that led to the shedding of blood on both sides. In the midst of battle, our brave companion heard one warrior shout, "Hasten, let us retreat: this man has struck us!"

Our friend thought to himself, "My guardians are spirits." Although he did not sense injury, the warriors claimed he had been struck by an arrow. Thus, the ghostly group made their way back to Egulac, only for our friend to return home, sharing tales of the supernatural clash that had occurred.

With the dawning of the sun, he joined his people around the fire, recounting the events with pride. However, as the hours wore on, a darkness unfolded within him. Suddenly, he fell to the ground, a shadowy substance escaping from his mouth. The gathered crowd watched in horror as the lifeless gaze of their friend was replaced with an expression of dread. He was gone.

Two brothers from the tribe of Pirouet set out on a moonlit night to the river bank, their intent on hunting seals. As they waited, the tranquility was unexpectedly disturbed by eerie war cries. They hiddeni behind a huge boulder, their hearts pounding with fear. Canoes emerged from the mist, their paddling echoing through the night. Six men filled this canoe, Maxanh did not hesitate to express his dissent. "I have no arrows," he announced. The others did not argue. They turned to the eldest, Neyap, who hesitantly agreed, boarding the canoe.

The men rowed inland, leaving Pirouet behind, to a village nestled amidst Kalama's verdant hills. Echoes of battle rang through the air, and the brothers hid as they prepared for war. As the cacophony grew, Neyap heard one of the warriors exclaim, "Quick, we must depart! That tribesman has been struck down."

Neyap's thoughts raced, "Perhaps they are demons," he pondered, "I am unharmed, but you, my friend - you have joined their cause." Suddenly, a scream pierced the night. A foreign, inhuman howl overtook their canoe, leaving Maxanh trembling and disoriented.

The mysterious warriors hastily returned to Pirouet, knowledge of the carnage they had inflicted and suffered silenced the conquered. Maxanh revealed the dark events, his voice filled with awe. "I sailed with the gods of war, and we exacted retribution. However, many lives were claimed, and I remain unscathed."

As the tide receded, the sun began to rise, but the transformation was not as peaceful. Maxanh's body convulsed, a liquid substance escaping from his lips. His face twisted into a grotesque expression, and with a terrible cry, he fell to the ground.

A collective gasp from the villagers tore through the stillness, an expression of sorrow mingled with fear. As the sun reached the zenith, Maxanh's lifeless body disappeared among the encroaching darkness. The gods of war had claimed another soul.

Two nights ago, two courageous youths from the village of Wahkeena ventured to the shores of the river in pursuit of elusive beaver. The scene was suddenly transformed as the tranquility of the night was shattered by the fog that rolled in, accompanied by haunting battle cries. The young men, sensing danger, retreated to the safety of the shore and concealed themselves behind a large boulder. "What do we make of this?" one young man asked, trembling with fear.

"We are invited to join their war party," the other responded, noticing that his friend's quiver was empty.

"Alas, I possess no arrows," the first youth replied, worried that his absence would be unnoticed by his loved ones back home. "But you," he urged, turning to the other, "should consider the opportunity."

Despite the entreaties, one young man hesitated, unwilling to risk his life in an unknown battle, while the other agreed to join the enemy's ranks. As the canoes proceeded inland, they reached a settlement on the opposite side of Mul diede. A fierce confrontation ensued, with the opposing sides causing significant casualties.

However, as the screen of war was gradually lifted, our protagonist began to feel a deep sense of unease. He now believed he was amongst the spirits who had come to claim more lives. Wounded but bewildered, he boarded a canoe and returned to the safety of his village.

The sun rose over the river as the tale unfolded, and the young warrior shared his captivating story with his people. Their initial awe transformed into horror, as his true condition was revealed. Blackened by the experiences of war, he embraced the life beyond, leaving his community in a state of profound sorrow.

In the stillness of a moonlit night, two youths from the Egulac tribe set out to the riverbank in pursuit of seals. The tranquility was soon disturbed by a thick fog and eerie war cries that echoed through the silence. In the end, the tales of 'accompanied ghosts' resurfaced, a testament to the unforgettable experience of the young man.

Under the moonlit riverbank, two youths from the village of Ya'amani set out on a seal hunting expedition. The night was tranquil, the water serene, but as they waited, the calm was disrupted by the sounds of distant war drums. They huddled behind a damp boulder, their hearts pounding.

Soon, canoes emerged from the mist, paddles slicing through the still water. Five stern-faced warriors approached, their eyes gleaming with intent.

"Come with us," they urged. "Our tribe needs brave warriors for this campaign. Your brother has agreed."

One youth hesitated, "I have no arrows."

"Fear not, they are in the canoe," they assured him. But when the young man refused, insisting he might be killed and his family unaware of his whereabouts, the warriors reluctantly let him return to his homes.

True to their word, the war party continued up the river towards the nameless village on the far side of Kalama. The clash of weapons rang out, and the scent of smoke and blood filled the air.

Back at the village, the returning youth gathered the villagers around a crackling campfire. He recounted his harrowing experience, describing the carnage he had witnessed and the deaths of many from both sides. His voice shook with adrenaline and awe as he finished, leaving everyone in wide-eyed silence.

As the sun began to rise, the young man collapsed, a dark ooze seeping from his lips. Horrified, the villagers assembled around him. An unearthly stillness fell over the camp as they realized he had indeed accompanied theWar Spirits, or ghosts, on their fateful war campaign. This was his final story to tell.
